Speaker.hpid: Mrs. A. Doyle Mrs. A. Doyle
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare, further to his reply to Parliamentary Question No. 625 of 5 December 1984, if he will explain how the use of one room with no food supplied could be considered board and lodging valued at £2,285.71.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Under the provisions of the Social Welfare Acts the value of any benefit or privilege enjoyed by an applicant for unemployment assistance must be taken into account in the assessment of his means. Where an applicant resides with a relative on a holding the net yearly income of the holding is divided between the members of the household on a weighted basis and the means are calculated on the weighting attributed to the applicant.

MainHeading.P: Following an investigation of the case of the person concerned by a social welfare officer the net profit of the holding on which he resided was calculated at £8,000 per annum. He resides there with his brother and nephew and on the basis of a weighted calculation the value of 2/7 of the net profit was attributed to him and accordingly the value of his board and lodging was calculated at £2,285.71 per annum.

It is open to any person who is not satisfied with the amount of means assessed against him to appeal and to have his means assessed by an appeals officer. A form for this purpose may be obtained at his local office.

Speaker.P: Only one confirmed case of injury or loss resulting from TB or Brucellosis testing within the last five years is on record. In that instance an ex-gratia payment of £225 was made to the herdowner as a totally exceptional measure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carey Mr. Carey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when a person (details supplied) in County Clare will be paid his calf subsidy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 667 and 668 together. The proceedings instituted by the Land Commission for the acquisition of these lands have been discontinued, in accordance with the provisions of the Land Acts. The question of distribution does not therefore arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the very serious lack of accommodation for family law cases to be held in private, even though they are entitled to the maximum privacy; and if he will immediately provide finance to have the matter resolved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am not aware of any lack of accommodation for the hearing of family law cases in private, though ancillary facilities including consultation facilities are not always what we would wish. The position in Dublin differs from that in the rest of the country.

In Dublin, where the Office of Public Works is responsible for the provision and maintenance of courthouse accommodation, the District Court and the High Court each has a specially provided family law courtroom, complete with waiting rooms and consultation rooms, in Ormond House, while similar facilities are available to the Circuit Court in Dolphin House.

Outside Dublin, while I am, of course, anxious that proper facilities be provided, the position is that responsibility for providing and maintaining court accommodation is vested by law in the local authorities. I have no power to make finance available to them for the purpose.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Criminal Injuries Compensation Tribunal.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the terms of reference of the Criminal Injuries Compensation Tribunal; and the year of its establishment.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of claims made to the Criminal Justice Compensation Tribunal, the number of claims accepted in full, the number of claims accepted in part, and the number rejected, for each year since its establishment.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the damages awarded by the Criminal Injuries Compensation Tribunal in each year since its establishment.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice where compensation forms for the Criminal Injuries Compensation Tribunal are available.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will make claim forms for the Criminal Injuries Compensation Tribunal available in Garda stations, post offices, legal aid centres and public offices of the Departments of Health and Social Welfare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 670 to 674, inclusive, together. The Criminal Injuries Compensation Tribunal was established in 1974 to operate the non-statutory scheme of compensation for personal injuries criminally inflicted. The scheme which is a detailed document and constitutes what no doubt the Deputy has in mind by “terms of reference” was laid before each House of the Oireachtas on 7 February 1974 and may be consulted in the Library. The tribunal is required by paragraph 19 of the scheme to make annual reports to the Minister for Justice which are to be presented to both Houses of the Oireachtas. Such reports have been presented for each year of the tribunal's operations up to and including 1981 and provide information as to the compensation awarded and the manner in which claims were dealt with up to and including that year. As regards the years 1982 and 1983 the total amount of compensation awarded was £2,599,745 and £3,490,224 respectively. The numbers of applications received were 1,112 and 1,417. Applications were dealt with as follows:

MainHeading.P: Statistics are not available under the exact headings requested by the Deputy.

Application forms are available from the tribunal. I am not aware that this leads to any hardship since the forms will be sent or given out in response to a simple letter or a telephone call — or, for anybody who happens to be near at hand, to a personal caller. While I would not exclude the possibility of some other small number of offices keeping the forms as well, if a real need for doing so were shown, the Deputy will appreciate from the relatively small numbers who apply that it would involve a wholly disproportionate amount of administrative waste for such forms to be stocked in offices as suggested, the staff of which would have the task of storing and keeping them available on the off-chance that somebody might, sometime, look for one.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey

Payment of the grant is a matter for the Commissioners of Public Works.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey

A suggested schedule of accommodation for the extension has been forwarded to County Mayo Vocational Education Committee. The Department are awaiting the agreement of the committee to the schedule and when this is received, a planning briefing meeting to initiate architectural planning of the project will be arranged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will, in the interests of safety of children and because of the very heavy traffic, permit CIE to operate a pick-up point at the end of Knockafanna Road for pupils attending Culleens national school and at present being transported to Killala.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: This matter is at present under consideration in my Department. The Deputy will be informed of the outcome in due course.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will, in view of her commitment to a deputation representing parents and teachers, expedite the placing of a contract for the construction of Culleens national school, Killala Road, Ballina, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department on 20 August 1984 authorised the Commissioners of Public Works to arrange for the invitation of tenders for the new building for Culleens national school, Killala Road, Ballina, County Mayo. I understand from the Commissioners that they expect to be able to report the outcome of their examination of tenders at an early date. My Department will then convey without delay to the school authorities a decision on the placing of a contract.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make a statement on the reasons for the delay in having badly needed extensions provided at Crossmolina boys' national school; if she is aware that furniture has been sanctioned for a room not yet constructed; and if she can state when work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department on 18 March 1984 sanctioned a grant towards the cost of extending Crossmolina national school, County Mayo, by the provision of a general purposes area. The grant covered the provision of standard physical education equipment for the area in question. The Commissioners of Public Works are at present attending to the preparation of the contract documents. I am asking the Commissioners to expedite this project as much as possible. It is not possible however to state at this stage when work may commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will make a statement on the present position in relation to the extension to Crossmolina girls' national school; and if she can state when work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed to the provision of an extension to Crossmolina girls' national school, County Mayo, comprising a general purpose room and the ancillary accommodation appropriate to the present staffing level. This represents a change of brief from the original proposal to provide one additional classroom plus a library-cum-medical room. The preparation of a revised sketch scheme is at present being undertaken by the Commissioners of Public Works. It is not possible at this stage of planning to state when work on the extension may commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Vocational Preparation and Training Programme.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has met with school authorities and teachers' unions in relation to the provision of vocational preparation courses; and if they have expressed any reservations in relation to any aspect of the courses.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the precise arrangements being made regarding the provision of a second year for vocational preparation courses and the form of certification to be given on completion of this course.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will give a complete list of all post primary schools by sector that have received sanction for a vocational preparation course; the number of pupils in each school availing of such a course; and the additional staff, either full time or part time, allocated to each school arising from this course.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 681, 682 and 683 together. During meetings which representatives of the school authorities and teachers' unions have had with me and officials of my Department discussions have taken place in regard to the introduction of the vocational preparation and training programme. These discussions have ranged over all aspects of the programme and I have noted the views of the interests concerned. These views are being taken into consideration by my Department in the context of the future development of the programme. The nature and content of a second year for the programme are being examined by my Department at present. However the introduction of this second year will be contingent on the availability of ESF funding.

The question of certification is also being examined in my Department at present and proposals in this regard will be brought forward for discussion with the relevant interests as a matter of urgency. It is not the practice to give details of the type requested by the Deputy in relation to individual schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour when redundancy payment will be made to a person (details supplied) in County Cork; and if he will take into account the fact that he was on bonus payment and also had the use of a company car when redundancy is being paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: An application for a statutory redundancy payment was received from the person concerned on 22 November 1984 and is under consideration. The application cannot be dealt with since the person concerned disputes the weekly wage to be used for the purpose of calculating the redundancy lump sum. In these circumstances he should make an appeal to the Employment Appeals Tribunal for a decision on the amount of the weekly wage. A copy of the appropriate form for making an appeal to the tribunal is being sent to the person concerned.

Under the provisions of the Redundancy Payments Acts, 1967 to 1979, a week's pay for the purpose of calculating a statutory redundancy lump sum may, in certain circumstances, take into account such items as bonuses and use of company car. However, where there is dispute as to the reckonability of such items the matter is for decision by the Employment Appeals Tribunal.
